Discussion 2

Links

Slides
Attendance and feedback

Concepts

  1. What are the components of a recursive function?
  2. How can we verify that a recursive function is correct?
  3. What is tree recursion?

Problems

Question 1

How many call frames are opened if you call decrease_to_one(decrement, 5)? What about decrease_to_one(half, 8)?

TOGGLE SOLUTION

The initial call to decrease_to_one will open a frame. In the body of decrease_to_one, f is called until n reaches 1. So the question is, how many times does it take to reach 1 from n by calling f on it? For decrease_to_one(decrement, 5), it'll take 4 calls to f (f(5), f(4), f(3), f(2)), and for decrease_to_one(half, 8), it'll take 3 calls to f (f(8), f(4), f(2)). Each of these calls requires a new frame, so the answers are 5 and 4.

Question 2

Fill in the blanks below so that the output is as follows.

TOGGLE SOLUTION


Explanation:
First, we see that the return value of bern(____________)(____________) is passed as an argument to hill and will be bound to the parameter ary. Notice that ary is being called with no arguments in the body of hill. That means that the entire expression bern(____________)(____________) must return a zero-argument function.

Now let's analyze the call expression itself. First, we evaluate the operator: bern(____________). This operator is itself a function call, and we know it must return a function. Well, that's already taken care of, because bern's return value is always the function san regardless of the input. So what should we pass through to it? Notice that bern's parameter ie is called on the string "It is unacceptable that " + ders. That must mean that our argument is a function, more specifically, a one-argument lambda function. So then we have this: Since I've named the lambda's parameter x, the entire string "It is unacceptable that " + ders will be bound to x when we execute this lambda. Keep in mind now that lambda x: ??? will be bound to the parameter ie.

Let's skip the lambda's body for now and move on what to put in the second set of parentheses. We've established that bern(lambda x: ???) will return san, so essentially bern(lambda x: ???)(____________) becomes san(_________). Figuring out what to pass through to san is easy. We see that the parameter ders will be added to the string "It is unacceptable that ". This is the only place in our code where we can concatenate strings, so ders must be bound to "women make less than men". So now all that's left is to write the body of the lambda:
Earlier I said that the entire expression above must return a zero-argument function that will be bound to ary inside of hill. How can we make that happen? Well the return value of that whole expression is actually just the return value of san (remember that bern(lambda x: ???)(____________) is basically san(_________)). san returns the value of ie called on "It is unacceptable that " + ders! Recall that ie is bound to the lambda function we already wrote in. Thus, for san to return a zero-arg function, our lambda must return a zero-arg function:
Let's regroup and go over what our "bindings" are so far. ie is bound to lambda x: lambda: ???. ary is bound to that inner lambda, lambda: ???. The parameter x to our first lambda will be bound to the string we want to print.

Now, to figure out what that inner lambda should return, we must turn back to hill. Our desired action is to print the string that is bound to x in the first lambda. hill takes care of the printing for us; it prints the return value of ary(). That means that our inner zero-argument lambda must return the string we want to print, which is bound to the parameter x of the outer lambda function. This completes the solution:
Important note #1: Throughout the explanation I said that certain variables are bound to lambda ... : .... I do not that the variables are literally bound to those lambda expressions; it was simply a clean way to refer to certain functions. Remember than lambda expressions are just unevaluated expressions just like 2+4. What I mean is that the variable is bound to the function object that that lambda expression creates.

Important note #2: I don't expect you to read through this lengthy explanation and totally understand everything that's going on. For that reason I highly recommend drawing out the environment diagram. You can find the solution to the environment diagram here.
